Incident.Summary: -Responded to a single vehicle accident VS. a guardrail barrier. -While making contact with the operator, I detected the odor of alcohol/marijuana.-The operator was placed through SFSTS, which resulted in DUI/DWI.-A Probable Cause Search was conducted on the vehicle located CDS Suspected marijuana.

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
Marked Unit MV-43 is NOT equipped with a camera.
Axon Body Camera footage was recorded.
 
Case # 23-MSP-008065
Defendant: Jalil Shamar Dukes
Date of Birth: 10/23/1996
Date of Arrest: 03/04/2023
Time of Arrest: 0426 Hours
DUI #: 23-063
 
CERTIFICATES AND TRAINING:
*I am trained to administer Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
*I have successfully completed Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (ARIDE) training in May of 2021.
*I am trained and certified to conduct preliminary breathalyzer tests by the Maryland State Police.
 
Narrative:
On March 4th, 2023 at approximately 0401 hours, I, TFC Kline (#7112), currently assigned to the Maryland State Police Rockville Barrack was on patrol, operating marked patrol vehicle "MV-43." At that time, myself and Corporal Moore (#5995), were dispatched to locate a single vehicle, disabled in lane 1 of the roadway, in the area of northbound I-270 and Falls Road, Rockville, Montgomery County, Maryland. Corporal Moore arrived on scene and located a passenger vehicle disabled in lane 1 with heavy front end damage and airbag deployment. The vehicle was identified as a white 2021 Hyundai Accent displaying Maryland registration "4EP0681." Based on my training, knowledge, and experience as a police officer, I immediately observed impairment from the male operator of the vehicle. A 5-year-old child was located in the rear of the vehicle, without a child safety seat. No injuries were observed on either the male operator and/or child. The male operator was identified by his Maryland driver's license as Jalil Shamar Dukes (B/M, DOB: 10/23/1996). Dukes was then asked to consent to voluntary Standardized Field Sobriety Tests, which he consented to take. Based on the clues that I observed roadside, Dukes was placed under arrest for suspicion of driving under the influence of alcohol. A probable cause search was conducted on the vehicle, which resulted in me locating 58 grams of suspected marijuana. The suspected marijuana was seized and transported to the Maryland State Police Rockville Barrack, which was processed per MSP policy.
 
Phase #1 - Vehicle in Motion
During the course of the investigation, I learned the white Hyundai Accent was traveling in the area of northbound I-270 and Falls Road in lane 1. At the time, the operator of the white Hyundai Accent, bearing Maryland registration "4EP0681," failed to maintain a single lane, which subsequently ran off-road onto the left shoulder, striking the concrete traffic barrier. The white Hyundai Accent displayed heavy front end damages and airbag deployment, which the concrete traffic barrier displayed minor State properly damages due to the impact of the collision.
 
Phase #2 - Personal Contact
Upon initial contact with the male operator of the white Hyundai Accent, I immediately detected the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage and an overwhelming odor of marijuana emanating from the operator's breath and/or person. His eyes were bloodshot and glassy and his movements were slow and abnormal. I asked the male operator if he was ok, which he advised that he was. I noticed a child in the rear of the vehicle (Lyric Dukes, B/F; DOB: 08/21/2017). The child was observed in the rear of the vehicle without a child safety seat. I immediately requested EMS to arrive on scene to check on the welfare of the child.  I asked the male operator what happened, which he advised he was working all day since 4 in the morning, and he was tired. The male operator advised he must have fell asleep. I asked the male operator how much alcohol he had recently, which he advised he had a little. He advised he had been up all night and the last drink he consumed was around 11pm. The male operator was upset and began to scream out loud due the circumstances. I then identified the male operator by his Maryland driver's license as Jalil Shamar Dukes (B/M, DOB: 10/23/1996). I then requested for Dukes to consent to a Standardized Field Sobriety Tests, which he consented to. While speaking with Dukes, the strong odor of alcohol was not only emanating from his person, but from his breath as well. I asked Dukes how much alcohol he had consumed, which he advised he was unsure. Dukes advised he got his child this week and went to his friend’s house to have a good time and sipped on drinks throughout the evening.
EMS arrived on scene to check on the welfare of the child. EMS advised the child's welfare, health and well-being was normal.
 
Phase #3 - Pre-Arrest Screening
The tests were conducted on the left shoulder of the roadway, in the area of northbound I-270 and Falls Road. The surface was wet, level, and free from obvious debris. Dukes displayed no visible injuries. The front facing emergency lights of my patrol vehicle were deactivated during all phases of testing.
I asked Dukes the following questions:
Daily/Regular Medications - NONE.
Glasses - NONE.
Contacts - NONE.
Injuries - NONE.
 
 
HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS TEST (6/6 clues displayed)
I used my pen as a stimulus and held it approximately 12 to 15 inches from Dukes’ eyes. His eyes displayed no resting nystagmus and his pupils were equal in size. His eyes also showed equal tracking. Dukes was advised to stand with his feet together and his hands down at his sides during the instructions/demonstration and throughout the test. I asked Dukes if he could see the tip of my stimulus, and he stated that he could. I observed his eyes to be bloodshot and glassy. Dukes was instructed to follow the stimulus with his eyes only, keeping his head still. After stating that he understood the instructions, Dukes attempted the test with the following results:
1. Lack of Smooth Pursuit - Present in both eyes.
2. Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation - Present in both eyes.
3. Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 degrees - Present in both eyes.
 
 
WALK AND TURN TEST (4/8 clues displayed)
Prior to Dukes performing the test, I explained and demonstrated how the test is conducted. Dukes was instructed to place his right foot directly in front of his left foot and touch heel-to-toe. Dukes was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his sides and to remain in the position until told to begin. Dukes was instructed to take a series of nine (9) heel-to-toe steps in a straight line. Dukes was to keep his hands flat at his sides, keep his eyes focused on his feet and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, it was explained and demonstrated, to keep his lead foot on the line, to take a series of small steps around, and to completely turn around 180 degrees. It was explained and demonstrated to Dukes that a second series of nine (9) heel-to-toe steps were to be performed identical to the first series. I instructed Dukes, that once the test begins to continue until instructed to stop. I then reminded Dukes to place his hands down by his sides, look down at his feet, and to count each step out loud. I asked Dukes if he understood the test, he confirmed that he understood.
 Instructional Stage
-Nothing to report.
 
Walking Stage (1st Nine Steps)
-Missed heel-to-toe on steps 3 and 5.
-Stepped off-line by more than a foots width on step 5.
 
The Turn
-Not completed properly, Dukes walked backwards for the second portion of the test.
 
Walking Stage (2nd Nine Steps)
-Missed heel-to-toe on steps 2-10.
-Too many steps (10 total backwards steps).
 
 
ONE LEG STAND (2/4 clues displayed)
Dukes was instructed to stand with his feet together and his hands flat to his sides while the test instructions and demonstration were given. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground in front of him approximately 6 inches, keeping his legs straight and his toes pointed out in front of him parallel to the ground. While his leg was raised, he was to count out loud by thousands (one thousand one, one thousand two, one thousand three...) and to continue counting until told to stop. After demonstrating the test, Dukes advised he understood. Dukes then raised his left foot off the ground to begin the test.
Balancing and Counting Stage
0-10 Seconds:
-Placed foot on the ground on multiple occasions.
 
10-20 Seconds:
-Placed foot on the ground on multiple occasions.
 
20-30 Seconds:
-Placed foot on the ground on multiple occasions.
-Raised arms by more than 6 inches from his sides.
 
Dukes was then placed under arrest for suspicion of driving under the influence of alcohol at approximately 0426 hours. Dukes was placed inside the front seat of my patrol vehicle. At that time, I detected the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage that was not present prior to placing him inside my vehicle.
 
Due to the strong odor of burnt marijuana emanating from the vehicle, a probable cause search was conducted. While searching the vehicle, I located the following inside a black computer bag, in the rear of the vehicle, behind the driver’s seat: One mason jar containing suspected marijuana. The suspected marijuana had an approximate weight of 58 grams. The suspected marijuana was seized and transported to the Maryland State Police Rockville barrack as evidence. The CDS suspected marijuana has a property held number (#P-315128), and the Civil Citation issued to Dukes was (#0Z46639201). I know the above seized evidence to be CDS suspected marijuana based on my experience as a police officer. I have received over 40 hours of training on the detection and recognition of CDS in the Maryland State Police Academy. I have made numerous CDS arrests that had received subsequent convictions in court.
 
ARREST:
Based on the following, I had reason to believe Dukes was driving a motor vehicle under the influence of alcohol:
 
-Glassy, bloodshot eyes.
-Strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from his breath and person.
-Negligent driving.
-Slurred speech.
-HGN Test: 6/6 clues displayed.
-Walk and Turn Test: 4/8 clues displayed.
-One Leg Stand Test: 2/4 clues displayed.
-Slow and lethargic movements.
-Admitted to consuming alcoholic beverages recently.
-At fault in motor vehicle collision.
-Traveled off the road.
-5 year old daughter not restrained in a child safety seat.
 
 
20 Minute Observation Period
Dukes and his daughter were transported to the Maryland State Police Rockville Barrack for further processing. Dukes was given a copy of the DR-15 Advice of Rights so he could follow along as the DR-15 Advice of Rights audio was played out loud in English. The English version audio can be found on mva.maryland.gov. Dukes signed the DR-15 at approximately 0500 hours acknowledging his consent to take the test. Sergeant Tribue (#5781), from the Maryland State Police Rockville Barrack, conducted the test for Dukes. Sergeant Tribue is a certified Intoximeter Technician in the state of Maryland. Dukes’ breath specimen was found to contain an alcohol concentration of .10 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath. Dukes was issued all pertinent documentation regarding the incident. Dukes and his daughter were released from the Maryland State Police Rockville Barrack to a sober family member at approximately 0637 hours.
 
All events occurred in Montgomery County, Maryland.
I request this case to be closed by arrest.
